all_summaries: This paper presents an efficient neural and numerical method for real-time spectrogram inversion, combining a lightweight CNN with complex least squares to achieve high-quality waveform reconstruction. Key innovations include a significantly smaller CNN (∼8k parameters) with reduced computation, a latency-increase strategy to halve CNN computation without sacrificing quality, and a fast numerical solver leveraging tridiagonal matrices for the second stage, enabling orders-of-magnitude faster processing compared to existing methods. The approach maintains high quality and low latency, outperforming alternatives in both efficiency and performance.

This paper proposes an efficient neural and numerical method for real-time speech spectrogram inversion, leveraging the Gradient Theorem to jointly estimate phases from STFT magnitudes. Key innovations include a significantly smaller and faster CNN (8.46k parameters, 0.27 GMAC/s) for the first stage, reduced computation by increasing latency with a look-ahead frame (halving computation without sacrificing quality), and a tridiagonal, positive-semidefinite linear system for the second stage, enabling orders-of-magnitude faster phase estimation. The method achieves high-quality results comparable to existing approaches, with reduced computational costs and latency, making it suitable for real-time applications.
